item.title: GSoCpedia: Chapter Five
item.description: ‚ÄúPatience is bitter, but its fruit is sweet.‚Äù ~ Aristotle If you have been following my blogs you’d know I was facing serious problems with my machine. For some reason it would auto-delete any file that I’m working on! (That’s automation for you üòµ) Given the current COVID situation, it was incredibly difficult to get a new machine. After being stuck for days, Voila! Project Status Update Meet I had one of the most eventful weeks so far, with so many things lined up one after the other.

item.title: GSoCpedia: The journey so far
item.description: ‚ÄúImagine a world in which every single human being can freely share in the sum of all knowledge.‚Äù Foreword Google Summer of Code (GSoC) is a global program focused on introducing students to open source software development. Students work on a 3 month programming project with an open source organization during their break from university. As a part of Google Summer of Code, student participants are paired with a mentor from the participating organizations, gaining exposure to real-world software development and techniques.

item.title: GSoCpedia: Chapter Four
item.description: ‚ÄúWith tests, we can change the behavior of our code quickly and verifiably. Without them, we really don‚Äôt know if our code is getting better or worse.‚Äù ~ Michael Feathers (Working Effectively with Legacy Code) One of the best experience in this duration was attending the TDD Workshop. The workshop was about learning basics of Test Driven Development - its rules and Red-Green-Refactor loop. The workshop was very interactive and all the participants worked together while writing code as well as refactoring it.

item.title: GSoCpedia: Chapter Three
item.description: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry if it doesn‚Äôt work right. If everything did, you‚Äôd be out of a job.‚Äù ~ Mosher‚Äôs Law of Software Engineering I would like to start this blog with one of the stories shared on the WaterCooler by James. (Read more about ‘WaterCooler’ in my previous blog.) Early in his career he worked in an aviation company in UK. The project was related to the network connectivity of the airplane during it’s entire journey.

item.title: Edit Distance: Day 31 of the May LeetCoding Challenge
item.description: ‚ÄúThe big optimizations come from refining the high-level design, not the individual routines.‚Äù ~ Steve McConnell Day 31 of the May LeetCoding Challenge by Leetcode Problem definition: Edit Distance Given two words word1 and word2, find the minimum number of operations required to convert word1 to word2. You have the following 3 operations permitted on a word: Insert a character Delete a character Replace a character Sample Testcase Testcase 1

item.title: GSoCpedia: Chapter Two
item.description: ‚ÄúIt’s not the Destination, It’s the journey.‚Äù ~ Ralph Waldo It’s been less than a month but this community has really grown on me. The past few weeks have been really eventful. A huge shoutout to my mentor, ≈Ωeljko for giving me the best on-boarding experience ever! (üì£ You can checkout his blog on GSoC here.) In this short span, I got to meet the entire QTE & Release Engineering team.

item.title: K Closest Points to Origin: Day 30 of the May LeetCoding Challenge
item.description: ‚ÄúData dominates. If you’ve chosen the right data structures and organized things well, the algorithms will almost always be self-evident. Data structures, not algorithms, are central to programming.‚Äù ~ Rob Pike Day 30 of the May LeetCoding Challenge by Leetcode Problem definition: K Closest Points to Origin We have a list of points on the plane. Find the K closest points to the origin (0, 0). (Here, the distance between two points on a plane is the Euclidean distance.

item.title: Course Schedule: Day 29 of the May LeetCoding Challenge
item.description: ‚ÄúData dominates. If you’ve chosen the right data structures and organized things well, the algorithms will almost always be self-evident. Data structures, not algorithms, are central to programming.‚Äù ~ Rob Pike Day 29 of the May LeetCoding Challenge by Leetcode Problem definition: Course Schedule There are a total of numCourses courses you have to take, labeled from 0 to numCourses-1. Some courses may have prerequisites, for example to take course 0 you have to first take course 1, which is expressed as a pair: [0,1]

item.title: Counting Bits: Day 28 of the May LeetCoding Challenge
item.description: ‚ÄúPremature optimization is the root of all evil.‚Äù ~ Donald Knuth Day 28 of the May LeetCoding Challenge by Leetcode Problem definition: Counting Bits Given a non negative integer number num. For every numbers i in the range 0 ‚â§ i ‚â§ num calculate the number of 1’s in their binary representation and return them as an array. Sample Testcase Testcase 1 Input: 2 Output: [0,1,1] Testcase 2

item.title: Possible Bipartition: Day 27 of the May LeetCoding Challenge
item.description: ‚ÄúWithout requirements or design, programming is the art of adding bugs to an empty text file.‚Äù ~ Louis Srygley Day 27 of the May LeetCoding Challenge by Leetcode Problem definition: Possible Bipartition Given a set of N people (numbered 1, 2, ..., N), we would like to split everyone into two groups of any size. Each person may dislike some other people, and they should not go into the same group.
